hello and uh thank you for joining my talk today i'll be talking about our experience in introducing a data mesh at
cmc markets my name is tarek i'm a principal core data engineer cmc markets offers an
extensive online financial trading platform that has been basically running successfully for a few
years so my plan is to give you some context about us where we started and then dive
into five lessons we learned along the data mesh journey
okay so to start it's fair to say that cmc market by its nature is very data
driven every part of the business whether it's trading risk or marketing relies heavily on data
we are now uh undertaking an ambitious transformation program and the goal of this is to enable the business to build
new products and innovate in an agile way so some of the key principles include the adoption of the public cloud
which is aws in our case we're also adopting cross-functional squad delivery model
self-service is an important aspect of that and the goal is to allow teams to be autonomous and to basically work in
parallel and innovate data is a core part of the transformation one way of looking at it
is that while we are building new products on the cloud most of the existing and valuable data
is within existing systems on premise so there's a gap to be bridged there
when we started this journey and we looked at the data situation at cmc markets what we found is that the data
was mostly decentralized which is a good thing but siloed what that means is that
you have the knowledge of the data and the ability to do work with that data often
coupled in a single team so as a data consumer you need first to find the data you need
and then ask and wait for some work to be done on this data for you this would result in queuing and other
inefficiencies for example and planned work for the data owners we also observed that there were limited
convention standards and norms around data shared across themes for example naming labeling common data formats and
so on so some common questions for the business are where's the data i need
how can i actually understand the data when i find it how can i trust it and then if i have some new data source
how do i make it available for new products and in a nutshell how do we innovate at scale when data is a
bottleneck so just to give you a visual representation of that so this is a
situation where we have a new product at the top of diagram in green we have the product owner first needing data to
build their product and then we have a few teams here within data silo within the team
some of the team owned their data some of them also have data from other teams so the first thing is to look for the
data once you identify what you need then you need to get the data that has been shaped for the needs of the data
owners to be exported because there has been no prior thinking of what it would
what would make it easy to consume for consumers new consumers for example
okay so we learned a few lessons along the data i would like now to share them with you
the first fundamental question in the data mesh is what data goes inside the data mission what data doesn't
there are obviously a few opinions that we observed in the community for us
we think all the data should go so we have this idea of data neutrality so data itself is neither analytical nor
operational use cases can be when people talk about analytical or operational claims this
often does not describe the data itself this describes the way the data is actually organized in software systems and people
around that in in organizations so uh to then uh decide what data needs
to go in data mesh we introduced two key ideas one is we borrowed the path helen's idea
of data on the inside and data on the outside and adapted it to our context then we also identified and introduced
the idea of fundamental data sources okay so the first thing is to understand
what data goes in data mesh so uh make this distinction between data on the inside which is any data that is private
to a team that is not needed by the rest of the organization this data on the outside and this data
is typically of common interest to the rest of the organization needs to be identified as such
and then we need to think hard about how to make it consumable so these goes this goes through things like
the schema the description the documentation the quality attributes of this data and and this data needs then to be
exposed and be part of the data mesh this distinction allows basically consumers to find the data they need but
also allows teams to maintain autonomy and decide on the best possible representation and technology to support
the work they do within their teams basically so the other key concept we introduced
is identifying fundamental data sources so you can think these in our domain as for example the tradable devices or the
trades so again rather than trying to observe existing data silos and just add some technology
to consolidate them we did a mapping exercise to try to follow the um
the data flows within the business and then we identified these data sources uh fundamental data sources and then we
followed them from the outside in
okay so now that we know what data sources we need to focus on or data sets in the data mesh let's talk about data
discovery so uh early on we also understood very quickly that data discovery is really
essential to build successful data mesh so you can think of a data discovery capability as
something needed for people which is it gives data consumers for example a
starting point to find on their own and self-serve the data they need
it also decouples them from the data producers or the data owners so they can actually
self-serve for data sources you need a way to onboard new data
sources onto the data mesh so if the data is decentralized you need to centralize the metadata so that it can
be found and queried and searched by the people also data discovery actually is a subset
of a bigger concept which is metadata management which is very useful for something like data governance
in terms of the concrete implementation we looked around and we found a couple of interesting
products we chose amuntzen which is an emerging but really good
open source project which started at lyft it has a great
community great traction the fact that it's open source allows us to extend it and customize it we already built some
custom data in gestures it has a very simple
architecture which is real plus that makes it easy to deploy on the cloud we did have to do some work
to make it fit within our approach to infrastructure and deployment uh basically
another key point about amundsen is that it's backed by graph database so the metadata is natively represented by
a graph so anything that requires connectivity like lineage or maybe complex ad hoc insights on the data
you can access the graph database and query that
okay this is just a very simple screenshot just to give you an idea of how amazon looks
it is really usable functional interface and this is a key point because the main target for data discovery platform for
us are the people in terms of our approach about how we
introduced edmonton again we identified this as an early requirement and we started iteratively so don't wait till
you have all your data sources onboarded or identified we can start with what we have and then refine as we go along
and i mentioned it's not just a tool to store the schema we saw a few other things for example the data owners the
classification the quality attributes how to access data documentation and other things
so in terms of the approach uh we because the whole organization um has
often a broad range of data sources we decentralize the curation of the
metadata and work with other people on other teams however because we're just starting the data mesh journey we
centralized the implementation of the technical workflow for the moment within the core data team
one very important distinction between data discovery and data catalog which is
and the focus is human not other for example etl uh processes although amundsen does have an
api uh the approach is evolutionary we are not trying to find the perfect taxonomy
of data and then impose it on on the business so really the focus is something that is usable by a wide range
of people who do not understand the data sources necessarily but need them rather than being extremely comprehensive
this is just quickly to bring together this idea of the data the metadata and
convention center norms this is literally a screenshot from a brainstorming session and one way of
looking at the different approaches and where data mesh fits so for example in in a data mesh the data
is decentralized uh the metadata is centralized uh and the convention standards and norms uh
are shared but they are emergent and collaborative whereas in the monolithic data platform
both the data and metadata are centralized and the conventional standards and norms tend to be shared in
a top-down way and in data silos which is our starting point the data is decentralized however
the metadata is decentralized well not shared so are
the conventional standards and norms so this is one sort of useful way we found to look at
our implementation and to guide it okay now the third point i'd like to
cover is the importance of natively accessible data for the data mesh and i would like to use an example to
illustrate that which is what we are implementing right now so one very important goal of data mesh
is to make data natively accessible uh on the cloud so on the new products and on premise now the advantage of uh
there are reasons why there are systems that are built on premise and so on and these reasons would include co-location
and latency and so on but if we are to build a really great product on the cloud we
need to make the data available in a really acceptable latency and in form that is consumable by the new products we need
so we started by uh the tradable prices uh stream
uh which is basically a latency data stream that we generate at cmc based on market prices and again we had to bridge
this gap between having this low latency stream on premise and make it available on the cloud
so the technology solution we picked for the job is aeron which is a low latency and reliable messaging
transport and the approach is to bridge the gap build the bridge with aeron the bridge
itself will be high fidelity so it will preserve the semantics of the data and to enable a variety of use cases on the
cloud that are decoupled from each other and decoupled from where these
this data stream is is produced once we have the data available on the
cloud then we can use it to build custom views as required by the different classes of
applications for example an event log or a snapshot of the latest prices
let's have a look at just this diagram that illustrates this so you can see at the left hand side we have the data
coming from the outside then at the bottom of the diagram we have the pricing engine generating this
fundamental data source of uh tradeable prices which is consumed by another system at the trading engine
then we have the avon bridge that then takes this data and in a reliable and
performant way makes it available on the cloud that then feeds into a kafka for example
for an event clog or dynamodb for a snapshot and then
the existing products or new products sorry on the cloud can consume this data
obviously to complete the picture we have to add an instant data discovery so we can actually advertise
all the different data sources we have on amundsen and then new consumers can
decide which data sources they want to consume so you can use the kafka one for example if they have really low latency
requirements they can use the native uh iron data source
okay so i covered most of the data centric and technical aspects so just before concluding i'd like to go
briefly through a couple of organizational aspects of the data mesh one is handling cross-cutting concerns
you can imagine that in a data mesh there are many cross-cutting concerns so these include
data engineering tooling cloud engineering some higher level cross-cultural
concerns like data protection security and governance so the challenge obviously is to handle all
these concerns consistently across deliverables that are autonomous and independent
uh we given the skill set that are needed we cannot really have a perfect spread of these skills in every team so
we cannot have a data engineer with knowledge of all these things and everything so what we do in this case we take advantage of the squad model so we
have identified smes that can then be part of a squad when needed when they need to
contribute their skills now from the other end you have senior stakeholders who have some obligations
for example data uh protection and these people can also participate in the
delivery process the iterative delivery process so that we can actually transform the requirements early on into
actual things we can include in our delivery okay so this is just a logical view of
the data mesh now to just put it all together you can see that now we have data domains
there's a distinction between data on the inside which is private to the domain and data on the outside
which has been shaped in a way that is consumable for other products
everything is all the metadata is basically centralized in data discovery platform uh you have data owners who
look after the data and then you have a product owner who can interact with the data discovery platform and in the
middle you have the smes who can facilitate and support the different activities that require their expertise
around data for example okay the final lesson is about data mesh
itself as a product so data mesh is a journey it's not where we started but at the same time it's not
just like one recipe it's not originally defined and it's not just like a technology
implementation so we have to take multiple iterative steps and we also need to imagine these steps and imagine
basically milestones in between and so on at the same time we have different people working on things that are part
of the bigger data mesh so we need to ensure that there is alignment in the approach
and also the different capabilities we built for the data mesh like for example in in the what i showed earlier the data
discovery or errand bridge are cohesive so we don't end up building
just uh different things that do not add up to something cohesive together so one way of looking at it is that data mesh
itself can be seen as a product a slightly different type of product so what we're doing now we're introducing
actually product ownership role around the data mesh to make sure that this cohesion is achieved and this of
we can assist every team that is joining the data mesh in on their journey uh again this is very sort of problem
solving engineering heavy role rather than a traditional uh product ownership fall and it's definitely not the
data on the role that we that is exists also in the data mesh
okay so just to conclude uh say just a word about uh database and

context is ideal for that and in general we found that the data mesh and the transformation initiative
we have share the same ethos so we have a decentralized collaborative approach and the goal is to allow scale at
autonomy at the same time and obviously data mesh has a strong
domain driven design foundation and this is the whole idea of the business needing to reorganize
itself around data domains again data transformation offers a great context for data mesh to be effective rather
than just localized or superficial in terms of technology
